instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message: I'm having some slight issues. I'm very new to this but on most of the videos I've watched from Rossman he says to check the power rails within the schematics first but that is for older machines, and on this machine there is no "Always On" page with the power rails, so I have no idea where even to start.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message: This was the closest I could find to the power rails page

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message: Start posting <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and 3V42 voltages...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message: Voltage on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>? That would be the place to start on the new ones. Any history liquid drop damage etc?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message: just checked the first one on the board that I saw and it appears that <CAPACITOR>C3121</CAPACITOR> is missing completely. No voltage on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> anywhere else on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message: Would I have to replace this with the exact same resistor from a donor board or what could I put there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message:
"resistor"
???
In the pic appears a capacitor.
Which is also marked as "NO STUFF"; do NOT solder anything there!!!

Post resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> and check all input fuses.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message: Yes check resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> it should at least be 5 volts, but if it's zero, it could be shorted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>:
<CAPACITOR>C3121</CAPACITOR>: 116 KOhms, 1.97V
<CAPACITOR>C8121</CAPACITOR>: 146 KOhms,1.99V
<CAPACITOR>C8123</CAPACITOR>: 135 KOhms, 1.72V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message:
"<CAPACITOR>C3121</CAPACITOR>: 116 KOhms, 1.97V"
Use diode mode (red probe to ground) for such kind of test.
And don't test the same line in various points; is useless...

If 1.97V is a diode mode reading, don't post again the end "V"; just confuses us.
Red probe to ground should get reading lower than 1.000 in diode mode.

Do you get any voltage at F3000/10?
If not, check both fuses and resistance to ground on them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message:
Sorry about that, bear with me I'm learning very quickly all sorts of stuff I can't keep track of it all lol, but okay I'll check.
<CAPACITOR>C3121</CAPACITOR>: Diode - 568
F3000 and F3010: 4.97 V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message:
So you get 0V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?
Nor even pulsing there?
This points to a problem with USB-C controllers.
Post resistance to ground an all power rails of <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200.

"Any history liquid drop damage etc?"
???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> PIN 1 and 2: 0V nor pulsing
<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> chips: 
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 133.8 KOHMS
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 63 OHMS
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> =  9 OMHS
Yes it has been dropeed also an update its not reading any voltage for <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> anymore

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message: <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> is still receiving 4.97 V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 9 OMHS"
Almost shorted; <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> is the first suspect there.
But check <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> first, just in case.
Pretty sure is not C/<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> issue...

Post resistance to ground for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> -- 8.6 OHMS
<CAPACITOR>C2890</CAPACITOR> to ground resistance 8.7 OHMS
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> -- 8.5OHMS to ground

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message:
all three are showing around 8.6 OHMS
 <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR>, <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> Resistance to ground

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message:
Post resistance between <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> (NOT to ground).
Seems that both <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200 are damaged...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message: The resistance between <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 17.6 OHMs

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on
threads.message:
Check the filter caps on both lines.
If OK, then bad chips...
